They know better when to (step up) the intensity. There's going to be ups and downs during the match,” Fonseca said. “I need to have more experience on this. I need to work more to stay mentally focused during the whole match.”Four-time major winner Carlos Alcaraz , 21, was all praise for Fonseca.“The way he played his first Grand Slam match against his first top-10 opponent, it's unbelievable,” the Spaniard said. “He’s someone I will see, he's going to be there. This is just the beginning of the year, but he's going to be there. We're going to put Joao Fonseca's name on the list of the best players in the world really soon.”Fonseca, born in Ipanema, Rio de Janeiro, idolizes Roger Federer , so much so that he tried to model his backhand like the Swiss’s flawless single-hander.“I tried for one week and then I have something in my elbow and I go to the two-handed again,” he said, adding, “Roger, inspires me.”The result aside it would be fair to say that the opening Grand Slam of the 2025 season showcased the best of the next generation -- 19-year-old Jakub Mensik , who plays Spaniard Alejandro Davidovich Fokina in the third round on Friday, having claimed his first top-10 win at a Grand Slam when he took down Casper Ruud, and American Alex Michelsen, who knocked out the 11th seed Stefanos Tsitsitpas, and will play the 19th seed Karen Khachanov on Saturday.American Taylor Fritz , the Australian Open’s fourth-seed, saluted the teenagers, saying he was impressed by their show.“When you are that age getting to play these big matches there's no expectations, no pressure,” he said, adding, “When I was younger, the top four or five was pretty ridiculous. We had Rafa (Nadal), Roger (Federer), Novak (Djokovic), Andy (Murray) and Stan (Wawrinka), all those guys at one time.”“It was tough to break through playing a top-8 seed,” Fritz said. “I think maybe now it's a little more winnable for the younger guys because all the top seeds aren't some of the best players of all time.”
Article Summary: Joao Fonseca beats Lorenzo Sonego 7-6 (6), 3-6,. 1-6, 6-3, 3- 6 in the second round of the Australian Open. The 18-year-old is the youngest player in the ATP’s Top-200. The Australian Open is the first Grand Slam of the 2025 season.

Article Title: Jannik Sinner roars back to move into Australian Open third round
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner. (Pic Credit - X)

World number one and reigning champion Jannik Sinner demonstrated resilience by advancing to the Australian Open third round in Melbourne on Thursday.Taylor Fritz delivered a commanding performance in his quest for his first major championship, whilst promising young talent Joao Fonseca narrowly lost in a gripping five-set contest.Daniil Medvedev , who finished runner-up to Sinner in Melbourne last year, is scheduled to face American teenager Learner Tien, 19.Sinner's 14-match streak of not dropping a set ended when Australian wildcard Tristan Schoolkate claimed the opening set. However, the Italian regained his composure to secure a 4-6, 6-4, 6-1, 6-3 victory against the world number 173 at Rod Laver Arena under cool, windy conditions.This marked Sinner's 16th consecutive win, sending a strong message to his next opponent, Marcos Giron."It's always tough to play against someone I don't know very well. He was playing much better than I was at the beginning," said the 23-year-old Italian, who also claimed the US Open last year."I have to be very happy with my performance and never take things for granted. Very glad to be in the next round."I can improve, yes, but I'll take it."Fourth-seeded Fritz secured his place in the third round against Gael Monfils with an impressive display of powerful tennis , having lost merely eight games in the tournament thus far.The American dominated on Margaret Court Arena, defeating Chilean qualifier Cristian Garin 6-2, 6-1, 6-0 in just 82 minutes.Fritz, who reached last year's US Open final, has spent just over three hours on court and maintains a perfect service record.Despite high praise from Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic, with the latter noting similarities to himself, the talented Fonseca fell short. After his remarkable upset of ninth seed Andrey Rublev, the Brazilian teenager succumbed to Italian Lorenzo Sonego 6-7 (6/8), 6-3, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3.Sonego will next face Hungary's Fabian Marozsan, who eliminated 17th seed Frances Tiafoe in five sets.Australian favourite Alex de Minaur efficiently dispatched American Tristan Boyer in straight sets, while 13th seed Holger Rune prevailed over Matteo Berrettini in four sets.
Article Summary: World number one Jannik Sinner beats Australian wildcard Tristan Schoolkate. Taylor Fritz cruises into the third round of the Australian Open in Melbourne. Joao Fonseca narrowly loses to Italian Lorenzo Sonego in five sets.

Article Title: N Sriram Balaji and Miguel Angel Reyes-Varela ease into Australian Open second round
Article Text:
N Sriram Balaji. (File Pic: Image Credit - X)

NEW DELHI: India's N Sriram Balaji and Mexican Miguel Angel Reyes-Varela progressed to the Australian Open 's second round, securing a dominant straight-sets victory against Robin Haase and Aleksandr Nedovyesov in Melbourne on Thursday.The partnership from India and Mexico overcame the Dutch-Kazakh combination with a score of 6-4, 6-3, completing the match efficiently in just over 60 minutes.The victorious pair demonstrated their superiority by delivering 23 winners, whilst their opponents managed only 16.They secured a break in the sixth game of the opening set, though immediately lost their advantage. Nevertheless, a crucial backhand winner in the tenth game secured them the set.The second set saw Haase and Nedovyesov falter with an unforced error in the eighth game, presenting a vital break opportunity. Balaji and Reyes-Varela seized this chance effectively to secure both the set and match.In other results, Rithvik Bollipalli joined fellow Indians Rohan Bopanna and Yuki Bhambri in departing the men's doubles competition.Bollipalli, playing alongside American Ryan Seggerman , succumbed to sixth seeds Harri Heliovaara of Finland and Britain's Henry Patten, losing 6-7, 1-6.
Article Summary: N Sriram Balaji and Miguel Angel Reyes-Varela beat Robin Haase and Aleksandr Nedovyesov 6-4, 6-3. Rithvik Bollipalli joined fellow Indians Rohan Bopanna and Yuki Bhambri in departing the men's doubles competition.

Article Title: Taylor Fritz donates Australian Open prize money to Los Angeles wildfire relief
Article Text:
Taylor Fritz reacts during his second round match against Cristian Garin at the Australian Open tennis. (AP)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

American tennis player Taylor Fritz , currently ranked world number four, has announced that he will donate his first-round prize money from the Australian Open to help victims of the devastating Los Angeles wildfires. The 27-year-old, who lives in California, made the decision after reaching the third round in Melbourne by defeating Chilean qualifier Cristian Garin in straight sets, 6-2, 6-1, 6-0.First-round prize money at the Australian Open amounts to AUS$132,000 (US$82,000).Fritz , who previously resided in LA for an extended period, expressed his concern for those affected by the wildfires and encouraged others to contribute to relief efforts."I just want everyone to obviously stay safe, it's just insane what has happened," said the 27-year-old."I'm going to be donating my first-round prize money to LA wildfire relief funds."It's really the least I can do. Southern California is my home and LA was my home for a long time."I'm just doing what I can possibly do to help and I would encourage anyone else who can donate to help because a lot of people really need it."The deadly fires, which began more than a week ago, have been fuelled by hurricane-force winds, resulting in the loss of two dozen lives and the destruction of large areas of the city. Several other tennis players, including Coco Gauff , Madison Keys , and Jessica Pegula, have expressed their shock and admiration for the firefighters' tireless efforts.Keys, who once lived in the LA area, donated $20,000 to the city's fire department "in support of the incredibly brave firefighters working tirelessly to protect the community." Pegula, the founder of the dog rescue charity A Lending Paw, has been using her online presence to share ways to help the hundreds of animals displaced by the fires.Naomi Osaka, who represents Japan but resides in Los Angeles, revealed on Monday that the wildfires were "three blocks" from her home, highlighting the severity of the situation.
Article Summary: Taylor Fritz will donate his first-round prize money from the Australian Open to help victims of the devastating Los Angeles wildfires. The 27-year-old, who lives in California, made the decision after reaching the third round in Melbourne by defeating Chilean qualifier Cristian Garin in straight sets.

Article Title: Iga Swiatek races into third round at Australian Open
Article Text:
Iga Swiatek (Image credit: Australian Open)

NEW DELHI: Iga Swiatek advanced to the Australian Open 's third round with a commanding 6-0, 6-2 victory over Rebecca Sramkova , marking her continued return to competition following a doping suspension in the previous year.The second-seeded player immediately established dominance by breaking Sramkova's serve in the opening game and maintained control throughout the match.The Slovakian player, ranked 49th globally and making her Grand Slam second-round debut, struggled against Swiatek's superior technique and forceful play.In the initial set lasting 27 minutes, Swiatek dominated by winning 64 percent of points on Sramkova's first serve, surrendering merely 10 points.The Rod Laver Arena audience warmly applauded when Sramkova finally secured her first game in the eighth game of the match.Swiatek maintained her authority throughout, securing victory in precisely 60 minutes."I felt really solid today and it was a really efficient game," said Swiatek. "I'm happy that I kept my focus."Her next opponent will be Emma Raducanu, the former US Open champion, who defeated Amanda Anisimova.Under new coach Wim Fissette, Swiatek is implementing fresh strategies as she pursues her first Australian Open championship.The five-time Grand Slam champion lost her top ranking to current champion Aryna Sabalenka last year, following a month-long suspension.Her previous performances in Melbourne have been modest, with her best result being a semi-final appearance in 2022.Swiatek has recently partnered with Fissette, Naomi Osaka's former coach, towards 2023's end.The Belgian coach has introduced a hitting partner for Swiatek's Australian campaign, a first for her, and she reports positive progress."He's been great," said Swiatek. "I feel like he's really supportive.""And you know being on the women's tour, I think it's not easy especially when most of the coaches are men. They also need to understand what we go through sometimes.""I feel like Wim is doing that very well."Swiatek pulled out of the WTA's late-season Asian swing in 2024 citing "personal matters" only for it later to emerge she had been under a one-month suspension for testing positive for a banned heart medication. She denies knowingly doping.
Article Summary: Iga Swiatek beats Rebecca Sramkova 6-0, 6-2 in second round of Australian Open. Second-seeded player returns to action after doping suspension last year. Swiateks next opponent will be former US Open champion Emma Raducanu.

Article Title: Sunflower-themed Naomi Osaka shines in Australian Open third round
Article Text:
Naomi Osaka. (AP Photo)

Siegemund shock:

Mensik powers through:

Late in the 32-minute opening set, perhaps during the changeover when staring at an emphatic 0-5 scoreline, Naomi Osaka 's vivid sunflower hair clips came off.It might've helped untether the Japanese's fierce groundstrokes as she won 18 of the next 23 games against Czech Karolina Muchova , who she had lost successive meetings to, most recently in New York, to move into the third round of a major for the first time since January 2022.Osaka, the two-time Melbourne Park champion, rallied from a set down to defeat the 20th seed 1-6, 6-1, 6-3 on Wednesday.The 27-year-old, who recently announced on social media that she and rapper boyfriend Cordae had parted ways, sported the sunflower theme, in her hair, ears and shoes, underlining the look was fitting for the Happy Slam."I don't know if anyone was able to take a very zoomed-in picture of my shoes, but on the side it says, 'The sun shines where you are'," she said of her tangerine-hued lace-ups, with sunflower accents in the front. "It was fitting to have a sunny theme (for here)."Osaka's gear contrasted the fickle Melbourne weather – dank and dismal; the crowd responded to it, getting into the contest from the get-go. Every cheer for Osaka was met with 'Do toho!' for the Muchova, 'go for it' in Czech, particularly in the decider when she trailed 2-5.The Japanese bounced up and down as she watched the ball sail long on her third match point after 1-hour and 57-minutes of riveting action.After pulling off what she called a 'revenge win' Osaka proceeded to school the full-house, saying 'revenge was competitive and a good thing'.The Osaka-Muchova match played on KIA Arena with a seating of 5000 as against the courts the four-time major winner is generally scheduled on like the Rod Laver Arena with a 15000 capacity waltzed to the tune of the crowd, who were fully involved in the contest, with fair support for both players."I don't really mind," Osaka said of the size of the court. "I think I'm the type of person that tries to focus on themselves a lot when playing, but I really did enjoy the crowd today. So if that's because it was a smaller court, then maybe I do enjoy smaller courts."Next up for Osaka is another 27-year-old mother Swiss Belinda Bencic, a former top-5, presently ranked 294. Bencic, whose daughter will turn one in April, leads their head-to-head 3-2."I love playing the big opponents, that's where I play my best tennis ," said Osaka, who put out Frenchwoman Caroline Garcia in the first round. "If I play better opponents as the rounds go on, it's more interesting because I feel like it's like the clash of Titans almost. I think the fans probably appreciate it."Osaka, who has been outspoken on a number of issues, said she was an athlete first and mother next when on the court."We are labelled 'moms,' of course. I think when you go on the tennis court, you just think of yourself as a tennis player," she said. "I don't want to say I've grown up with her (Bencic), but we've definitely seen each other on Tour. I think it's really cool that she also had a baby, and she came back, as well."It wasn't the best of days for China's fifth seed Zheng Qinwen who fell 6-7 (3), 3-6 to the spirited Laura Siegemund. The German authored the tournament's first major upset.Olympic gold medallist Zheng came into the event as a possible title contender at a career-high ranking of No.5, but the defence and defiance of the World No.97 Siegemund won out in 2 hours and 16 minutes of play.Some 24-hours after Brazil's 18-year-old Joao Fonseca knocked out the world No.9 Andrey Rublev, 19-year-old Czech Jakub Mensik put out the sixth seeded Casper Ruud 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4 firing 62 winners to reach the third round.Mensik, who hit 22 aces, sparked the Margaret Court Arena where he clinched the win in 2-hours and 44-minutes.
Article Summary: Osaka, the two-time Melbourne Park champion, rallied from a set down to defeat the 20th seed. The 27-year-old, who recently announced on social media that she and rapper boyfriend Cordae had parted ways, sported the sunflower theme in her hair, ears and shoes.

Article Title: Katie Boulter and Alex de Minaur spark couple vibes at Melbourne Park
Article Text:
(Agency Photo)

Katie Boulter and Alex de Minaur have been dating for five years, as of December they were engaged, and at Melbourne Park they are sparking couple vibes.Shortly after clinching his first-round win over Dutchman Botic van de Zandschulp, De Minaur, the world No. 8, raced to the KIA Arena to watch the deciding set of Boulter's first-round clash against Canada's Rebecca Marino.Boulter, the world No.25, was in a spot of bother after losing the second set but turned around the match with the Aussie No.1 cheering at courtside."Having Alex there, he is my support system," Boulter said. "He has helped me through the rough and good moments. He kind of leads me, I would say. He has shown what an incredible tennis player he is and he's ranked top 10 in the world and has been there for a whole year, which is not an easy thing to do.""Having him come out and support me means pretty much everything to me. Having that extra positivity from my bench makes the difference," the 28-year-old Briton said.Boulter's scores kept flashing on Rod Laver Arena when the Sydney-born De Minaur was on court."It is tough just because there is a scoreboard that keeps alternating with different results throughout the day, and then all of a sudden you get the score of Katie's match," he said. "You try not to pay too much attention and focus on yourself, but the fact that it's always coming around makes it difficult."Boulter, 28 from Leicester, wished she could see De Minaur's score when she was playing."It's obviously difficult knowing he's playing a match and you're kind of hearing cheers here and there and you're hoping that's for him, but you never know," she said. "Look I'm fully focused on what I'm doing, most of the time I'm not thinking about it at all, but of course I'm hoping he wins and that he's out there for the rest of my match!"In Thursday's second-round action, De Minaur takes on American qualifier Tristan Boyer, second match on Rod Laver Arena. On Court No.3, an adjacent show court, Boulter plays Veronica Kudermetova, in the fourth match. The Aussie can make it comfortably for Boulter's engagement.
Article Summary: Katie Boulter and Alex de Minaur have been dating for five years, as of December they were engaged, and at Melbourne Park they are sparking couple vibes. The Aussie No. 8 raced to the KIA Arena to watch the deciding set of Bouler's first- round clash against Canada's Rebecca Marino.

Article Title: Australian Open 2025: Alexander Zverev beats Pedro Martinez to cruise into third round
Article Text:
Alexander Zverev (AP Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

NEW DELHI: World number two Alexander Zverev maintained his pursuit of the Australian Open title with a convincing straight-sets victory over Spain's Pedro Martinez in the second round on Wednesday. The German showcased his dominance, securing a 6-1, 6-4, 6-1 win in under two hours on Rod Laver Arena .Zverev, who reached the semi-finals at the Australian Open last year, will now face Britain's Jacob Fearnley in the third round.Fearnley advanced after overcoming Frenchman Arthur Cazaux in a four-set encounter.The 27-year-old German, known for his marathon matches, jokingly acknowledged his desire to shorten the duration of his matches as he pursues his maiden Grand Slam title."Usually I play 7-6 in the fifth, four-and-a-half hours, but I'm getting older," Zverev quipped. "I have to maybe shorten things up a little bit. Hopefully more to come in the later rounds."Zverev's dominance was evident from the outset as he broke Martinez's serve immediately and powered through the first set in just 34 minutes, striking 10 winners.Although Martinez, ranked 44th, showed resilience in the second set, Zverev's relentless pressure and precise groundstrokes earned him a crucial break and a two-set lead.The third set followed a similar pattern, with Zverev securing an early break and maintaining his momentum to secure a straightforward victory.Despite enjoying one of his best seasons in 2022, a Grand Slam title has eluded Zverev for nearly a decade, with runner-up finishes at the 2020 US Open and the 2022 French Open being his closest efforts so far.
Article Summary: World number two Alexander Zverev beats Pedro Martinez in straight-sets. German will now face Britain's Jacob Fearnley in the third round. The 27-year-old jokingly acknowledged his desire to shorten the duration of his matches as he pursues his maiden Grand Slam title.

Article Title: Kiran George, a ray of hope for India
Article Text:
Kiran George. (Getty Images)

NEW DELHI: When the initial draw was made for men's singles at the 2025 India Open, three Indians were looking to lead India's challenge. Paris Olympics semifinalist Lakshya Sen , 2023 World Championships bronze-medallist HS Prannoy , and youngster Priyanshu Rajawat had the responsibility of going deep into the tournament.After a spate of withdrawals from several foreign players, two more Indians were added to the men's singles draw - former world No. Kidambi Srikanth and a rising star Kiran George .While Srikanth withdrew after not being able to reach Delhi in time for his first-round match, Lakshya, Prannoy and Priyanshu suffered contrasting first-round defeats. Only Kiran was able to cross the first-round hurdle. On Thursday, he improved his showing to enter the quarterfinals."It's all about being relentless and just playing patiently. That's what has worked for me over the years," Kiran said about his run.Kiran hails from Kochi, Kerala. Born in a family of badminton players, Kiran began his tryst with the racket and shuttle at a young age. His father George Thomas is a former national champion and an Arjuna awardee. His mother Preetha was a state level player. Elder brother Arun is also an international - a doubles specialist.Kiran's father enrolled him at the Prakash Padukone Badminton Academy in Bengaluru. He gained recognition after winning a silver in the Under-17 Boys singles in the Asia Youth Championships in 2016. By 2019, he had secured his first international title, winning the Ghana International. In 2021, he won the Polish International title after defeating Singapore's Jason Teh in the final.In 2022, Kiran won the Odisha Open - a BWF Super 100 tournament - marking his first World Tour title. In 2023, Kiran pulled off one of the biggest achievements of his career by defeating former All-England champion and current world No. 1 Shi Yuqi of China at the Thailand Open - a Super 500 tournament.
Article Summary: Kiran George is one of three Indians in the men's singles draw at the 2025 India Open. Lakshya Sen, HS Prannoy and Priyanshu Rajawat had the responsibility of going deep into the tournament. Former world No. 1 Kidambi Srikanth and rising star Kiran George were added to the draw.

Article Title: India Open: Sindhu marches on
Article Text:
PV Sindhu. (Getty Images)

Kiran George,

Satwik-Chirag

also cruise to quarters

NEW DELHI: It was an electric atmosphere. PV Sindhu in full flight is a sight to watch. At 5 feet 11 inches, when Sindhu jumps for a smash, she easily reaches somewhere near 8 feet. From that height, Sindhu's winners are deadly. There is no chance for the opponent to lift the shuttle back into play. And when she reels off one smash after another, there is absolutely no breathing space for her rival.Japan's world No.46 Manami Suizu was at the receiving end of Sindhu's power-packed strokes on Thursday, as the Indian shuttler waltzed through to the quarterfinal of the India Open Super 750 tournament here at the KD Jadhav Indoor Stadium.It was a killer display from Sindhu as she gave a lesson on attacking badminton to Suizu, winning 21-15, 21-13. Sindhu will now face Paris Olympics bronze medallist and fourth seed Gregoria Mariska Tunjung of Indonesia in the quarters.The match saw Sindhu leap in the air multiple times, and each time there was a winner, the crowd raucously cheered the point. She made a strong start, leading 11-6 at the break. Although Suizu briefly narrowed the gap to 11-13 and 13-14, Sindhu was always a step ahead, with the Japanese player unable to cope with the Indian's powerful smashes. Sindhu continued to hit deep returns to trouble Suizu. Soon, she was 20-14 ahead and sealed the game when the Japanese hit the net.After the change of sides, Sindhu raced to a 5-0 lead. The second game was all about the Indian as she found cross-court winners at will, quickly establishing a dominant 11-2 lead at the interval, and it became clear that Suizu had no answers."After a break, what I liked about my game today was my movement and my attacks were working well," Sindhu said after her win.The men's doubles pair of Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty had to recover from a first-game reversal to beat the Japanese pair of Kenya Mitsuhashi and Hiroki Okamura 20-22, 21-14, 21-16 and progress to the last-8.It looked like Satwik and Chirag would also take a straight games route to the quarters when they raced to an 18-14 lead and had a game point at 20-19 in the opening game, but they could not convert it and eventually lost the game. The blip, however, did not turn into a crisis, as the pair quickly took control of the action in the second game and then maintained the advantage to win in 1 hour 11 minutes.Youngster Kiran George, who was given a last-minute entry for the tournament due to a spate of withdrawals from many top foreign players, saved six game points against Frenchman Alex Lanier to win 22-20, 21-13 and enter his maiden quarterfinals of a Super 750 event. The 24-year-old will take on Chinese shuttler Hong Yang Weng in the last-8 clash. It was not a fruitful day for other Indian contenders with women's doubles combination of Ashwini Ponnappa/ Tanisha Crasto , Rutuparna Panda/Swetaparna Panda and mixed doubles pairs of Dhruv Kapila/Tanisha and Ashith Surya/Amrutha Pramuthesh getting knocked out in the second round.Two-time Olympic gold medallist Viktor Axelsen beat Singapore's Jia Heng Jason 21-11, 21-14 to reach the quarterfinal, while former world champion Loh Kean Yew outwitted sixth seed Kodai Naraoka of Japan 21-12, 24-22.In women's singles, top seed and Paris Olympics champion An Se-Young steamrolled Thailand's Ratchanok Intanon 21-15, 21-8 to progress to the last-8.
Article Summary: PV Sindhu beats Manami Suizu 21-15, 21-13 to reach quarterfinals of India Open. Top seed and Paris Olympics champion An Se-Young steamrolled Thailand's Ratchanok Intanon. Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty recover from first- game reversal to beat Japanese pair of Kenya Mitsuhashi and Hiroki Okamura.
